* Parents/guardians can go to the Adopt a Firebird Senior 2020 Facebook page and post your Senior's name, photo(s) (optional) and a bit about your Senior. * You can then do porch drop-offs or deliveries of your special gifts for your adopted Senior.

This is a fun way to let our Seniors know that we're thinking of them as they finish their careers at Fairmont High School.

A big THANK YOU to Pam Pennington for coordinating the "Adopt a Firebird Senior 2020" movement, and to all those who are participating!

As a reminder...if you do have a technology question, please call our KCS Technology Help Desk at 937-499-2626.

GOVERNOR EXTENDS SCHOOL CLOSURES TO MAY 1

During his news conference on Monday afternoon, Gov. Mike DeWine announced the extension of mandated school closures across Ohio until May 1.

This news did not surprise us, as Gov. DeWine had previously indicated during his daily reports that the trajectory of the Coronavirus could necessitate keeping schools closed longer than the initial April 3rd date.

Our teachers are hard at work and will continue developing effective E-Learning lessons and maintaining regular contact with their students and parents throughout the school closures.

Our students in kindergarten and 1st grade will move to all-online learning in the next week or two. Our K-1 teachers will be in touch with their parents/guardians with more details on the move to E-Learning for our K-1 students.

As always, we are happy to answer any of your questions. Please email all questions and concerns to KCSCOVID19Response@ketteringschools.org.

Pups for People, a new club at Fairmont High School, is hosting an Awareness and Fundraising Event on March 8.

Pups for People was started by a group of Oakwood High School students and has expanded this year to Fairmont High School, under the leadership of Fairmont student, Grayson Fogel.

Each year, Pups for People works to raise the funds needed to give someone a service dog with full training and all other necessities covered.

The Pups for People Awareness Event will be held at Oakwood High School on March 8, from 1-3 p.m. The event will include a silent auction, an obstacle course, carnival games, food and the chance to meet some service dogs.

Pups for People is raising funds this year to provide a six-year-old Centerville student with a service dog. Past recipients of service dogs through Pups for People include Ahmad Doucet, Ally Moran and Lili Rodriguez.

For more information about Pups for People, please visit their website at https://pupsforpeople16.wixsite.com/mysite

Sharing a "feel-good story of the week" from our friends at the Kettering Backpack Program! ❤️🍏

One of the most empowering ideas for children is Service Learning. Kids learn to give back to the community and become star citizens! Kelly Adkins is a shining example of putting this into action with her children.

Her children, Chloe and Jacob, put back half of all the money they earn and then donate it to a charity of their choice. Chole & Jacob recently chose the Kettering Backpack program and donated $100. Chloe shared that she wanted to donate to Kettering Backpack because one of her friends gets food from the backpack program, and she wanted to help.

Thank you Kelly for teaching your children to have a giving heart and a HUGE thank you to Chloe & Jacob for helping to provide over 20 students with food this weekend!❤️❤️❤️

If you would like more information about the Kettering Backpack Program and how you can make a donation to this worthy organization, please visit their website at https://www.ketteringbackpack.org/

Message from Superintendent Scott Inskeep:

On Thursday, January 9, the Kettering City Schools lost a true advocate of public education in Mr. James Trent.

Mr. Trent was an avid supporter of Fairmont Athletics and the Kettering City Schools Music and Arts programs. He cared deeply about our students and staff. Mr. Trent served the district for more than six decades as a teacher, principal, superintendent and long-standing board member, and always put students first.

Our thoughts and prayers go out to the Trent family.

Visitation for Jim Trent is scheduled from 11 a.m. to 2 p.m., on Sunday, January 12, with a memorial service to follow at 2 p.m. Visitation and memorial service will take place in Trent Arena on the Fairmont High School campus.

— Scott Inskeep

Congratulations to Indian Riffle Elementary School’s principal, Debbie Beiter; and teachers, Amanda Zickefoose, Julie Ray and Beth Frederick. The quartet is at the Blue Ribbon Schools of Excellence National Conference as we speak, and will be presenting "Once Upon a Team: Helping Students Achieve to Infinity and Beyond Through Data-Driven Decisions and Interventions" tomorrow as part of the four-day conference.

The session they are presenting “will show how our school makes data-driven decisions in a team setting and implements those decisions through a daily intervention hour at each grade level, after-school programs so that all learners can be successful.”

As Dan Von Handorf, assistant superintendent of Teaching & Learning tweeted, “It is a HUGE honor to (be invited) to present to a national audience. Congratulations IR!!”

Indian Riffle Elementary is a 2018 Blue Ribbon School of Excellence.
